docs.lead_paragraph: Patrick Kwan, an antismoking advocate, writes that “there is no safe level of secondhand smoke exposure.”
docs.snippet: Patrick Kwan, an antismoking advocate, writes that “there is no safe level of secondhand smoke exposure.”

docs.lead_paragraph: When Melissa Orion’s unvaccinated baby contracted whooping cough, she was grateful for modern medicine - its emergency rooms and even its antibiotics.

headline.main: Softer, Less Strident Outreach May Help Calm U.S. Vaccine Skeptics
headline.print_headline: Softer, Less Strident Outreach May Help Calm U.S. Vaccine Skeptics

docs.snippet: When Melissa Orion’s unvaccinated baby contracted whooping cough, she was grateful for modern medicine - its emergency rooms and even its antibiotics.

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine being able to identify who is likely to develop a particular disease — and then stop the disorder before it starts.

headline.main: Johnson & Johnson Projects Aim to Spot Who'll Get a Disease
headline.print_headline: Johnson & Johnson Projects Aim to Spot Who'll Get a Disease

docs.lead_paragraph: A new analysis suggests that an additional 60,000 deaths a year in the United States are linked to smoking.

headline.main: Smoking’s Toll on Health Is Even Worse Than Previously Thought, a Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Smoking’s Toll on Health Is Even Worse Than Previously Thought, a Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study in The New England Journal of Medicine suggests at least five diseases and 60,000 annual deaths should be linked to tobacco in United States; smoking is already tied to nearly half a million US deaths a year from 21 diseases including 12 forms of cancer.
docs.snippet: A new analysis suggests that an additional 60,000 deaths a year in the United States are linked to smoking.

docs.lead_paragraph: Breast cancer, prostate cancer, and even routine infections. A new report ties these and other maladies to smoking and says an additional 60,000 to 120,000 deaths each year in the United States are probably due to tobacco use.

headline.main: Study Ties More Deaths, Types of Disease, to Smoking
headline.print_headline: Study Ties More Deaths, Types of Disease, to Smoking

docs.snippet: Breast cancer, prostate cancer, and even routine infections. A new report ties these and other maladies to smoking and says an additional 60,000 to 120,000 deaths each year in the United States are probably due to tobacco use.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama is right to push a personalized approach to health care forward, though high costs remain a concern.
docs.abstract: Editorial praises proposal contained in Pres Obama's budget that promotes practice of 'personalized medicine,' also known as 'precision medicine'; notes that while practice may not live up to hype of curing diseases that are currently incurable, increasing funding for personalized medicine could revolutionize care and would almost certainly result in best quality of care.
docs.snippet: President Obama is right to push a personalized approach to health care forward, though high costs remain a concern.
